seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

Nun-bar-&c;e-gunu a name of Nisaba faithfully gave birth to &X;&X;, she brought her up in her &X;&X; and suckled her at her breasts full of good milk. The &X;&X; of the young girl burgeoned, and she became full of flourishing beauty. In the &X;&X; of Nisaba, at the gate of the E-zagin, &X;&X; she stood, the object of admiration, like a tall, beautifully shaped cow.

At that time Enlil had not yet been given a wife in the E-kur; Ninlil's name was not yet famous in the Ki-ur. After travelling through Sumer and to the ends of the universe, he &X;&X;; in his search throughout the Land, Enlil, the Great Mountain, stopped at Ere&c;. As he looked around there, he found the woman of his choice. He approached her and, overflowing with joy, engaged her in conversation: I will make you perfect in a queen's dress; after standing in the street, you will be &X;&X;. How impressed I am by your beauty, even if you are a shameless person! In her youthful inexperience Sud answered Enlil: If I want to stand proudly at our gate, who dares to give me a bad reputation? What are your intentions? Why have you come here? &X;&X; from my sight! Others (?) had already tried to deceive &X;&X;, and made her (?) angry. Enlil &X;&X; answered Sud, &X;&X; standing closer to her: Come, I want to speak to you! I will have a talk with you about your becoming my wife. Kiss me, my lady of most beautiful eyes -- the matter rests in your hands. But the words had barely left his mouth when, right in front of him, she went into the house.

The heart of the wise lord pounded. He called for Nuska. What is your wish? He gave the following instructions to him: I want you to go back to Ere&c;, the city of Nisaba, the city whose foundations are august. Do not delay! Repeat to her what I am going to tell you: I am a young man, I have sent this message to you because of my wish: I want to take your daughter as wife. Give me your consent. I will send you presents in my name, &X;&X; my marriage gifts. I am Enlil, the descendant and offspring of An&c;ar, the noble, the lord of heaven and earth. The name of your daughter shall become Ninlil, and all the foreign countries shall &X;&X; it. I will present her with the &G;a-&g;i&c;-&c;ua as her storehouse. I will give her the Ki-ur to be her beloved private quarters. She shall sit
1 ms. has instead: live with me in the E-kur, my
1 ms. has instead: the august dais. She shall determine fates. She shall apportion the divine powers among the Anuna, the great gods. And as for you, I will place in your hands the lives of the black-headed people. When you get there, let the woman I have chosen for her beauty &X;&X; her mother. Do not go to her empty-handed, but take her some jewellery in your left hand. Waste no time. Return with her answer quickly.

When Nuska, the head of the assembly, had received Enlil's instructions, he wasted no time &X;&X;; he directed his steps to Ere&c;. He entered E-zagin, the residence of Nanibgal a name of Nisaba and prostrated himself before Nanibgal on her dais. &X;&X; of Enlil &X;&X;, and she (?) asked him &X;&X;: &X;&X; what &X;&X;?
(Nuska speaks:) &X;&X; Sud &X;&X;. What you have told me &X;&X;. Then Nanibgal went on speaking flatteringly to the minister: Adviser, fit for his (?) king, ever observant (?)! Who like you could give counsel daily to the Great Mountain? How could I contest the king's message which his slave has received? If there is truth in what you have told me -- and may there be no falsehood -- who could reject one who bestows such exceedingly great favours? &X;&X; makes our mood and hearts happy. Let us consider that amends have been made. By bringing the marriage gifts and the presents in his name the insult is wiped away. Tell him: You shall become my son-in-law; do as you wish! Tell Enlil, the Great Mountain: Do as you wish! Let his sister come from her side, and she shall accompany Sud from here. Aruru shall become Sud's sister-in-law: let her be shown the household. Inform your lord thus in his august Ki-ur. Repeat this to Enlil in the privacy of his holy bedchamber.

(Enlil speaks:) From now on, a woman shall be the &X;&X;; a foreign woman shall be the mistress of the house. May my beautiful wife, who was born by holy Nisaba, be Ezina, the growing grain, the life of Sumer. When you appear in the furrows like a beautiful young girl, may I&c;kur, the canal inspector, be your provider, supplying you with water from the ground. The height of the year is marked with your new prime flax and your new prime grain; Enlil and Ninlil procreate them (?) as desired.
The harvest crop raises its head high for the great festival of Enlil. The scribal art, the tablets decorated with writing, the stylus, the tablet board, reckoning and calculating, adding and subtracting, the shining measuring rope, the &X;&X;, the head of the surveyor's peg, the measuring rod, the marking of the boundaries, and the &X;&X; are fittingly in your hands. The farmer (?) &X;&X;. Woman, the proudest among the Great Princes, &X;&X;, from now on, Sud &X;&X; Ninlil &X;&X;.
A holy song of praise &X;&X;. Enlil and Ninlil &X;&X;!

Your &X;&X; which I have determined for you should be fulfilled; &X;&X; with head held high into the E&c;-ma&h;.

Aruru grasped her &X;&X; and &X;&X; her away into the E&c;-ma&h;. She brought her into the shining E-kur, and poured the best perfume over her face. In the sleeping quarters, in the flowered bed fragrant like a cedar forest, Enlil made (?) love to his wife and took great pleasure in it. He sat her (?) on his dais appropriate to the status of Enlil, and made the people pray to her. The lord whose statements are powerful also determined a fate for the Lady Aruru, the woman of his favour; he gave her the name Nintur, the 'Lady who gives birth', the 'Lady who spreads her knees'. He made beautiful En-batibira's perhaps a name of Aruru countenance, &X;&X;. He presented her with the &X;&X; of a mistress, everything pertaining to women that no man must see, and &X;&X;.
As the presents are given in the shrine Nibru, a holy song of praise is sung. Enlil, the lord of the countries, &X;&X;.
